title: Is the Bahá'í Faith a cult? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. However, there is a problem with the concept of covenant-breaking, which no longer seems appropriate in the current context and has been used to silence any internal dissent within the Baha’i Faith. Although the notion of covenant-breaking has produced some cult-like aspects in Baha’i practice, a cult generally is hard to get out of. Leaving the Baha’i Faith is easy. Nevertheless, for those who’ve been forced out or forced into compliance concerning their silence on the many failures and abuses of the Baha’i Administrative Order—not horrible abuses like the cover-up of sexual abuse, but abuses of self-harming actions on part of the Administrative Order, itself, and the virtual coup of the liberal faction (often erroneously conceived as a conservative faction) within the Baha’i Administrative Order … To be a Baha’i and hold a position of influence in society at large, or within the Baha’i Administration Order is to have to limit your thoughts to the party line, in just the same way as members of the Chinese Communist Party do. Now, having said that let me also concede that on the other hand threading the needle between the overt conformity of a political organization such as the CCP and the modern idolatry of worshiping at the altar of individual autonomy is a tricky business under the best of circumstances. Nevertheless, there are many events in recent Baha’i history that suggest that out of fear of losing the appearance of cohesion—Baha’is are terrified of factionalism—the Administrative Order has overreacted causing many of it’s most prominent members to leave. This has also happened out of cronyism, conspiracy, and the prejudices of individual Persian Baha’is. To be clear it doesn’t appear that any of those involved necessarily have bad intentions, outside of simple self-interest. Nevertheless, in the effort to protect the faith it does appear that the very life is being strangled from it. Along these lines, it seems that there is something seriously wrong with how the Baha’i Administrative Order has developed. All of the elected Universal House of Justice members now come from the same single Baha’i institution, i.e. the International Teaching Center. What appears to have happened is that a culture of self-insular belief has caused the faith to stall, and anybody who speaks out about this within the Baha’i faith is silenced (it may be that before the Baha’i Faith starts growing again it will have to virtually collapse). In this sense then it does admittedly seem cult-like but only because it’s a religion. Most people who say the Baha’i Faith is a cult wouldn’t say that the Democrat party in the U.S. or the CCP is a cult (although the latter literally is a cult)? This same process of the closing down of the diversity of thought can be seen in all them. In this sense, the danger of being declared a covenant-breaker (despite its 19th century, fundamentalist like language) is not any different than becoming a persona non grata in the modern Democratic party, you’re going to lose a great many friends, acquaintances, business contacts and the like—hell, it may even cost you your marriage. In China, you could be prosecuted for some made-up crime, jailed and sometimes although this rarely happens to politicians even executed. Along the lines of the last statement. the term cult also isn’t necessarily pejorative. Again, the CCP is literally a cult—alright bad example as that only reinforces the pejorative connotations. However, it’s just that most cults in the modern era have had tended toward certain negative characteristics, so the term’s usage has changed in some contexts to reflect this. However, this isn’t as helpful as it might first appear when conceptualizing religious practices, as all religions really start out as cults. For example, Christianity was once a Jewish cult—and Judaism, itself, literally began as the cult of Abraham (every one of Abraham’s family including the servants had to be circumcised after Abraham). In a similar way, the Babi religion could be called an Islamic cult. At this point, some readers may wonder how I know so much about the Baha’i Faith outside of just the study of religion more generally. Well, I’ve had close relationships with a lot of Baha’is over the course of my life that began with one particular very close Baha’i friend in my youth. Now, this person is a very model of sober New England pragmatism. He’s always been as mature and level headed as a person could be. However, I remember this one time in particular when I brought up Juan Cole, a very prominent former Baha’i and secular academic. Now Juan Cole was never declared a covenant-breaker or otherwise officially censored by the Baha’i Faith, but you wouldn’t know that from my friend’s irrational animosity towards the mere mentioning of his name. It’s important to note here that according to Juan Cole, he was threatened with being declared a covenant-breaker because of his association with some other Baha’is (none of them declared covenant breakers) and an incident I won’t go in to but suffice to say for which there are many different perspectives about what actually happened, which lead to a censure of a “group” within the Baha’i Faith, and so Cole voluntary left the faith. Although, the official statement of the National Spiritual Assembly of the U.S. is that Juan Cole was never threatened with being declared a covenant-breaker. Already this might very well sound too weird and cultish for a lot of people. This is what I’ve meant by self-harming abuses above. Imagine, a Baha’i Faith that never spoke of covenant-braking in any situation not directly involving Baha’u’llah’s own family, but where maybe there was more externalized division? I bet such an organization would appear more attractive than does the current one. So what’s the point? If one has ever had an experience like this with a Baha’i one could be excused for feeling like there is something cult-like about the Baha’i Faith. Nevertheless, I’ve experienced the exact same emotional reaction from friends who are Democrats (or were just Bernie supporters) while attempting to speak positively about some of President Trump’s policies (and some of these persons don’t talk to me anymore). BTW, for many Baha’is, the very act of mentioning above might be taken as a subversive act, an act of deliberate sabotage by attempting to sow division within the Baha’i Faith. Outside of the fact, that I have no such intention, can you see the problem? It is the same problem that potentially could exist in any organization and often is on full display today as for example, we see it playing out on a national level today in the U.S. as both the Democrat and Republican parties accuse the other of deliberately attempting to obstruct the pursuit of justice. In other words, was the original investigation politically motivated and an investigation of the investigation now justified or is the investigation of the investigation really just the thing that’s being politically motivated? What you personally believe is almost certainly influenced by more general political ideology than an of the actual facts. Ironically, the Baha’i Faith touts itself as being immune to this, but as with so many things where a blind spot exists, often enough, boogymen are seen there instead. However, this doesn’t make it a cult, but rather just an organization that projects a degree of paranoia into situations where legitimate disagreement exists, exactly because it feels these disagreements are a threat to it—and in this case a very particular threat, i.e. the threat to reveal the fact that the Baha’i Faith’s image of a singular unity is actually an illusion, maintained in some cases through the overt suppression of any suggestion of disunity, which was, itself, justified in the name of unity. Still doesn’t make it a cult though, and in fact, my answer in focusing on a particular issue may come across as unintentionally negative. There are negative aspects to every human organization, however, there are also some exceptionally positive an even uniquely positive things about the Baha’i Faith (and other answers to this question have done a great job in illustrating them). Finally, despite whatever may be said of the Baha’i Administrative Order in practice the life of Baha’u’llah was an incomparable testimony of his great spiritual realization, even among other religious figures like Jesus, Shakyamuni, Muhammad, Baha’u’llah stands out—is the outstanding example. I would encourage every fair-minded person to read his writing and investigate his person.
